physDesc.p: Two pages typewritten in black ink. Mrs. Richard Aldington 44 Mechlenburgh Square London, W.C. England is the typed address given for H. D. in the top left corner of the first page. Unsigned.

editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following:

body.p: The enclosed letter was opened by me by mistake. The other letters lay over it, and I did not see your name until after I had opened it and saw that it began "Dear Hilda," and I am sending it to you envelope and all that you may see that it was not altogether extraordinary that I should have opened it.

I wonder if you ever got my book>. Fletcher got his copy, which I sent at the same time as I sent yours, but I have not heard yet from any of the others I sent to England. If you did not get it, please let me know and I will send you another copy. I hope you like the essay on you. People are calling it the "almost lyrical appreciation of 'H.D.'." Also, I am anxious to receive that biographical material about Richard as soon as possible, as I must begin to prepare my lectures shortly. Also I should like some news.

I think Richard must be an officer from what you say, and your mother tells me that he may be sent to the Eastern front, but I do not feel that I know anything definite, and I should be awfully glad to be brought up to date.

I sent Richard’s letter and poems to Brown. I do not think I like these rhymed things quite as much as Richard’s vers libre, but neither does he, as he says in the letter. I am not quite like the rest of you – everything that interests me turns into poetry, and just now I cannot get away from the war. I am writing a series called "Phantasms of War" for "The Independent," and I am sending you enclosed the first one which I think may interest you. It may not be what Richard calls art, but somehow I cannot divorce art from life, and if Homer made art out of the Trojan war, it seems to me we ought to be able to do the same with this war. Anyhow, I am trying and if I fail – well, it is all in the day’s work.
This is not much of a letter, but there is not much to say. I do nothing but work, and the whole country is given over to war preparations.
body.closer: Write soon and with a great deal of love to you both, Affectionately yours,
